EDITORIAL.
OMETIME ago one of the weekly journals published an article which
urged, in a half-serious way, the appointment of a professor-ofthings-in-general on every college faculty. The writer perceived the
fact (which, indeed, does not need to be pointed out to thoughtful college men) that the enormous broadening of the range of learning at
the present time, and the rage for specialization, are producing onesided men in our universities. Thus even in Johns Hopkins, when
a class reaches its senior year, it is divided up into the biology men,
and the chemists, and the Latinists, and the athletic men, and so on.
In spite of compulsory studies, the degree of A. B. is getting to mean
less and less a 'well-rounded education." For this reason, our writer suggested the creation
of a professor who should make it his duty to stimulate the students to look beyond their
special courses. While, as we all know, the range of tastes and studies is too great for any
one man to be such a professor-of-things-in-general to all the student-body, it is possible that
every student have a private course of his own. The writer finds his course-of-things-ingeneral in a little class, tucked away in the corner, and frequented by but three or four. The
instructor does not consider it necessary to limit himself to the strict letter of his subject, but
often takes the opportunity to digress and discuss art, politics, and the topics of the day.
Of course, not every study permits treatment of this kind. The writer has the good
fortune to be a member of another class, in an entirely different department. Owing to the
nature of the subject, the instructor must occupy himself with a great mass of detail and
minor differences. But he does not stop there. Through the bewildering maze of his
material he presents the great principles of a great science in such a way that his students
take delight in going outside the work of the class to discover and learn for themselves.
Unfortunate the Johns Hopkins man who has not upon his schedule at least one
course-of-things-in-general; and happy he who finds in every study a broadening and stimulating influence.

E have read with interest the first two articles in The Independent regarding American Universities. In these two are treated Harvard
and Yale. If we were choosing our college from the facts thus presented we should choose Yale, notwithstanding the writer of the
series considers Harvard the better.
It seems strange to us that a college man, as Dr. Slosson is,
should not understand what is meant by college democracy. There
VVV;
;V„trigVArsis in the mind of every present-day college man a clearly defined idea
!Or'OV'er
of
college democracy and this idea is the same all over the American
:Of V V
college world. Dr. Slosson merely sees the striving after it, and
imagines that because the strivings take different form that college democracy is different in
each institution.
A college is democratic when each student is first of all, a college man, that is a Hopkins man, etc., second, a fraternity or club man, and last of all an individual with personal
tastes
A class is democratic when its members in an election vote for the men they think best
fitted for the offices, and fraternity brothers do not vote for fraternity brothers, and non-frat.
men for non-frat. men, regardless of their qualifications for the place.
A student is democratic when, for instance, in voting for the captain of an athletic
team he will vote for the man he personally detests, if he thinks he is the best man for the job.
The Yale custom of frowning upon valets and automobiles, is to prevent the University
from being divided up into a rich and poor class.
It is not the use of Greek letters that is primarily objected to at Princeton; it is the
modern Greek-letter fraternity system which, in some cases, breaks the University up into a
number of small cliques, and is thus a foe to college democracy.
In other words college democracy strives to develop first of all a Yale man, a Princeton
man, etc., and incidentally, if desired, a frat. or society man.
It strives to place every student upon an equal footing in college affairs.
It strives to produce college unity.
It differs from college spirit in being internal, whereas college- spirit is external, altho
they are by no means independent.

UST as this issue of the NEWS-LETTER is going to press, the daily
papers make the important announcement that the trustees of the
university have decided to institute an Advisory Council of Alumni.
This council is to advise the trustees in their actions, to hustle for
Homewood, and in general to bridge the gulf between the powers
that be and the student, past and present.
From an undergraduate point of view, the innovation is good
all around. We believe that much of the half-heartedness of the
C
C. 11
alumni has been due to the fact that they have hardly even had the
4L.IZs St

privilege of making suggestions as to the conduct of the university.
A body of men who have done so much for science, for letter;, and for the public service, will
surely do much for their alma mater if given half a chance.
Dr. E. F. Slosson, author of the much-discussed articles in The indePendenl, remarks upon
the difference between the alumni of the Western and Eastern universities. In the West they
have been extremely radical, sometimes going to.the Legislature to force the State University
faculties to make innovations; in the East they have been morbidly conservative,in many cases.
We believe that the Johns Hopkins alumni will go neither to one extreme nor to the other,
but will pull together with trustees, faculty, and students for a wisely-planned, steady progress.
Won't we all make a fine team when we get a-going?

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE OPAL RING.
"Yes," said my friend, Jean, the village
priest. "In following my duties as priest of
these pious, but ignorant, people, I have
been called upon to be present at many deathbeds. At almost all of these I have heard the
stories of queer lives. Perhaps the most
startling story I have ever heard, and, at least,
one that will always remain in my mind as
the most awful, was among the first I heard
in this parish and, indeed, it happened at my
second visit to a dying man."
My old friend stopped and seemed to be
lost in a deep reverie. I saw a shudder run
through his body and an indescribable look
came into his face as he thought again of the
scene. Knowing him well, I did not hurry
him, but sal still, smoking an old clay pipe
and drinking ale, until with a sigh the old
priest began his tale.
"To begin with, you must know something
of the old fellow who told me this biography.
He lived in the old house that still stands on
the road leading from the village into the
forest, and allowed no one to come near his
house but his servant, who had been his constant friend and companion for sixty years.
When I undertook this charge I was told to
leave Daniel—this was the only name he had
as far as the villagers were concerned—alone,
and I am ashamed to say that I did as I was
bidden, for he developed a most interesting
character.
"About a year after my arrival, the people
began to notice that the servant had been
neither in the market nor stores for some
time. One old man in the parish became
very curious and, venturing one night to the
house, looked in the only window and saw
the old man Daniel sitting on a low chair beside a rough bed on which his faithful serGreatly
vant lay tossing and groaning.
alarmed he came to me at once and told me
what he had seen. I immediately seized my
medicine case and rushed to the lonely house.
I knocked repeatedly and, as no one opened
the door. I pushed my way into the only
room. There the old man still sat, looking at
his sick servant. I saw at once that he was
dying in a burning fever and I did all I could
to make his last moments comfortable. During
my efforts Daniel sat dazed watching my

efforts in an indifferent manner. When his
servant died he got up, walked around the
room and, running to me, said sharply, "you
have done enough, now go! Come again one
week from tonight!"
"The next Friday night I presented myself
at his door, and he opened it and admitted me
into the bare room. In one corner stood the
rude bed, in another a small, fireless stove, in
another a few clothes hung upon the wall, and
in another, leaning against the wall, stood a
pick and shovel with fresh dirt upon them.
I guessed that he had just buried his old
companion. In the centre of the room stood
an old table, covered with books. On it there
was a bottle of wine, a battered plate filled
with cakes, glasses, and a large red lamp
which cast a glow over everything. There
were two large arm chairs, on either side
of the table, which looked out of keeping
with the other furniture of the room.
"Daniel motioned me into one of these
chairs and there we sat for some time, silently
looking at each other. At last the old man
got up, filled my glass with the rare old wine
and, after pouring out a second glassful, sat
down. So we sat for the remainder of the
evening. While there, my glances took in
all the books on the table and I saw, with a
great shock, that there lay a well worn Bible,
surrounded by every kind of fiction, I was
greatly surprised, for my host was a small
harsh, stern old man with a diabolical look in
his eyes, and I had not expected to find a
Bible in his house. When at last I arose to
go, the old gentleman said in his sharp tone,
'Come again next week,' and let ine out the
door.
"This happened for several weeks, until at
last a kind of friendship sprang up between
us. Then we often sat until the wee small
hours discussing matters pertaining to religion and politics. I soon found out that my
friend knew more than I. Although I often
tried to get him to tell me of his former life,
he would always shut up like a clam when I
mentioned the past, and so I learned to curb
my'curiosity.
"Things went on in this fashion for a year,
until one Friday night, as usual, I walked
down the road toward my friend's house,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

thinking of the old man and wondering what
tale of sorrow he could tell if he would. As
I neared the house, I saw with alarm that
th2re was no light shining fi 0:11.the window.
I knocked, but got no response. When at
last I pushed the door open I heard a low
groan from the bed.
Rushing across I
grasped my friend's hand and felt his rapid
pulse. Instantly I knew that he was dying
from the same fever that had carried off his
old servant a few months before, and that I
could do nothing for him.
He asked for water, and when I gave it
to him drank eagerly, and then said, 'Sit
down, I want to tell you something.' I did
as he asked and then listened, with many
interruptions for water, to a story such as I
have never heard -since.
"'Father, you have been very kind to me,
and beforel die I want to tell this and ask
you to bury me according to the Church.'
"Here the old man stopped and drew a
long breath, and then he continued:
"'There was once a rich man in America
who had an only son. This son was the only
joy the old man had, and in him he centered
his hopes and his highest ambitions. He
gave his boy everything he wanted, and,
after his education was complete, he sent him
abroad for travel and further learning. But
the son was very ungrateful, and, after being
turned out by his father, he went into the
West and lived the rough life of a cowboy.
There he met a young girl to whom he
declared his love. She told him she loved
him, but refused to marry him until he proved
himself a man. Determined to win her, the
young man left the State and his old companions and began a new life. Before going he
went to the girl and gave her a heavy ring,
set with a large opal, and told her he would
come back some day for the ring and herself.
Several years went by, and at last the young
man felt himself the man he should be. As he
walked through the woods to their oldtrysting place, he saw a young couple walking
towards to him with their arms around each
other. As he himself was a lover, he stepped
behind a tree in order to let the pair pass him
undisturbed. As they drew nearer, something
about the girl seemed familiar, and a sudden
fear seized him. When at last they drew

5

near to him, he saw that the girl was his
sweetheart. Without a word he fired two
shots at the pair; the young man fell dead,
and the girl fell mortally wounded. Without
a word the young fellow jumped from behind
the tree, fired another shot into the dead man,
and then turned to the girl. She had fainted,
and he bent over her and kissed her. This
kiss seemed to revive her, for she threw her
arms around his neck and whispered: 'Jack,
I knew you would come back. You see, here
is your ring. Take it. You have killed my
brother. I forgive
"Here the dying man stopped short, and,
after some moments of quiet breathing, passed
away. I sat there for some time lost in
gloomy thought."
Here my friend stopped, and, with a deep
sigh, handed me a simple, heavy gold ring,
set with a large, clear opal.
X. Y. Z.

RECENT LECTURES.
An unusually full and varied course of lectures
has been provided this year by the university.
One or another of the various lecture rooms
has been in use almost every day.
Professor A. V. Williams Jackson, of
Columbia, has been lecturing on "The Religion of Persia:"
Fabian Franklin, Ph.D., formerly professor
of mathematics, is giving a series of ten
lectures upon "The Principles of Political
Economy."
Professor Felix Schelling, of the University
of Pennsylvania, has completed a series upon
"The Elizabethan Drama," given before the
English seminary.
Dr. Stevenson, of Rutgers, is lecturing
upon "The Age of Discovery" before the
historical seminary.
Dr. David M. Robinson, associate professor
of classical archaeology, spoke upon "Stages
in the Life of Ancient Greece" on the evening
of February 5th.
Dr. 0. L. Fassig, of the Maryland State
Weather Bureau, gave a series of lectures on
"Meteorology" before the department of
geology.
The February meeting of the Scientific
Association, and the address of Mr. Ben
Greet, are reported elsewhere in this issue.

THE HISTORY OF LACROSSE AT
JOHNS HOPKINS.
By WILLIAM C. SCHMFOSSER.
November 10, 1908.

)11linued from lasl issue).
1893.

The lacrosse season of 1893 was a success
in two ways: first, from the financial point of
view, and secondly, from that of the caliber
of the team turned out. Six games were
played and Hopkins won four of these and
second place in the Lacrosse League.
The Hullabaloo of 1894 treats the 1893
season as follows: '`In our first game we
extended to our visitors, the College of the
City of New York, a warm reception, for
which Baltimore Lacrosse teams are justly
famous, by defeating them by a score of 9-1.
In the second game we received an unpleasant surprise. Awed by the former renown
of the famous Druids, our team seemed to go
into a state of lethargy from which it did not
emerge until the game had ended. The
defeat on the whole, however, was beneficial,
as it pointed out the weak points, and aroused
in the members of the team the determination
to remedy its defects. After defeating the
Athletic Club of the Schuylkill Navy, the
first championship game of the season was
played with Stevens. It was an extremely interesting and well-played game in which
Hopkins showed themselves the better ill all
round work and won by a score 6-3. Lehigh

was our next opponent. Their team work
was brilliant and showed from the outset that
they were to win. At the end of the firsthalf the score was a tie, but in the secondhalf their magnificent training made itself
felt and we were easily defeated by a score of
6-3."

'`Our team closed its season very pleasantly
by defeating the Athletic Club of Schuylkill
at Philadelphia.The work of the team throughout the season was good and showed a marked
improvement over the work of the previous
year. The training was more vigorously
adhered to and the team work much improved.
Too much stress, however, was placed upon
'body work' which in many instances interfered materially with the proper use of the
stick."
It is interesting to note that already at that
time the coaches had trouble in developing all.
evenly balanced team with reference to body
work" and ''stick work."
A study of the accounts of the games as
given in the newspapers of that day show
that Janney, Roszel, Symington, Straus and
the other attack men carry off most of the
glory. Occasionally we read of the long
throws of T. D. Penniman and a stop by the
goal-keeper, but seldom of the other defense
players; therefore, we hesitate in giving
these men all the credit for the good work;
no doubt every man did his share.
The team was composed of these:
J. B. Crenshaw, goal; T. D. Penniman,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

point; P. M. Dawson, cover point; F. C.
Newton, first defense; W. S. Baer, second
defense; F. K. Cameron, third defense; T. F.
P. Cameron, centre; S. S. Janney, first
attack; B. M. Roszel, second attack; W. S.
Symington, third attack; T. E. Straus, out
home; B. Phinizy, in home.
Substitutes —W. H. Crampton; B. 13. Cone;
T. D. Penniman, captain; C. W. Baldwin,
manager.
Lacrosse Committee—B. M. Roszel, W. S.
Symington, W. S. Baer.
1894.
As to the team of 1894 we get very enthusiastic accounts showing that lacrosse was by
no means at that time on the wane in Baltimore, and in fact the attendance at the several
games played here rather showed a healthy
growing interest on the part of the general
public.
One writer tells us that ``the work of the
Hopkins team during the past season, notwithstanding the fact that it won only the
second place, was most satisfactory. Active
practice began early in the spring, and continued without interruption until the final
championship game. Enough cannot be said
in praise of the conscientious way in which
nearly the entire team entered into training."
After reading this I was surprised to find that
the record of games played that year showed
that as a matter of fact Hopkins had won only
one, beating Lehigh 6 to 4. Stevens, the
Druids and Cornell gloried over '`the Black
and the Blue" with the following scores respectively 7 to 5, 3 to 1, and 6 to 0.
The game with Cornell at Ithaca was quite
an undertaking. In fact it was then the longest trip a Hopkins team of any kind had ever
made, and the writer believes this record still
holds good today. The great obstacle to overcome was the question of financing, as the
Athletic Association did not have much of a
working fund and the guarantees were small.
In addition to the games mentioned above,
the University played two early practice
games: one with the East Branch Y. M. C.
A. and the other with the Catonsville Lacrosse
Club. The former was not much of a game
to test the Hopkins team because some of 'the
Black and the Blue men played on the Y.

7

M. C. A. team. This game will always be
remembered, however, by an amusing incident
which took place. It was in the latter part
of the first-half when after a missed shot at
goal the ball went behind the same. With
true Hopkins spirit, Lupton, who was that day
playing for Y. M. C. A. and Lilly, centre, for
our team, started after the ball. Lilly badly
checked Lupton who to prepare himself for a
good return check, threw off his cap. It is
remarkable to relate, but the cap fell directly
on the ball and neither Lupton nor Lilly
could locate the ball. After some consternation the tricky sphere was located and the
game went on.
In the Catonsville game nothing of peculiar
interest occurred, except that Janney temporarily had his knee sprained. It may be
of interest to posterity to know that this
Janney knee" was a remarkable and valuable asset to any lacrosse team, as it always
managed to get sprained when the Hopkins
players were winded, but could be reduced to
working condition again in a few minutes.
The men who composed our team that year
were:
J. F. Mitchell, goal; T. D. Penniman,
point; P. M. Dawson, cover point; F. K.
Cameron, first defense; J. B. Crenshaw,
second defense; T. E. Straus, third defense;
S. S. Janney, centre; B. M. Roszel, first
attack; T. F. P. Cameron; second attack; W.
S. Symington, third attack; M. Hill, out
home; G. H. Hodges, in home.
Substitutes—A. R. Stevens; B. Bande; T.
E. P. Cameron, captain; J. E. Shaw; A. C.
Bryan; J. Hall Pleasants, Jr., manager.
J. Hall Pleasants, Jr. was Secretary and
Treasurer of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
Association.
1895.
We who follow the modern lacrosse teams
at Hopkins are rather amused to read how
the Hullabaloo of 1896 gives the boys of that
year a pat on the back for doing such conscientious practice and training.
They
started in about the first of April and continued until after the last game in May. We
also read that the lacrosse men — with few
exceptions went into training on pledges so
that when the championship season came, the
men were in first rate physical condition and

THE NEWS-LETTER.

this enabled them to make a creditable showing." We can understand that having no
cage at their disposal, it was practically impossible for them to get any practice up to
April first, if the spring of 1895 was a late
one; but why there should be exceptions to
the training list, history does not show.
It was unfortunate that the management
was able to schedule only one practice game,
and that with the Maryland Athletic Club
which was just sallying forth with a lacrosse
team. This game was won by Hopkins
under the leadership of T. F. Cameron by a
score of 10-0.
Our first championship game that year was
with Stevens at Union Park. Among other
things the papers vouch the information that
-the day was a fairly good one for lacrosse,
although there was a sprinkling of rain, and
a little too much wind at times. The attendance was quite good, a large number of Hopkins students with black and blue flags and
banners encouraging their team with college
yells, repeated at every possible opportunity
offered;" that -the visitors excelled in team
work, but the Baltimoreans were stronger
individually;" that .`Janney's superb playing
was the feature;" that ``Captain Cameron's
leg was injured early in the game, and his
usually fine work was thereby much impeded;"
that ``the Hopkins team was greatly strengthened by Mitchell and Sidney Cone, the former
by his splendid work between the goal posts,
saving what looked like many a sure goal;"
that "Cone was everywhere in the Hopkins
defense field, and again and again he returned
the rubber to the Hopkins attack field by his
long throws" and lastly that ''the Stevens
manager will protest the game, claiming that
two of the Johns Hopkins players are not
bona-fide students." No doubt the manager
discovered that he was in error. The game
ended in favor of Hopkins by a score of 6-3.
Next came our fatal trip to South Bethlehem. Several of the men had not recovered
from the Stevens game, and history tells us
that the mainstay of our attack was so seriously hurt that he was using a cane until just
before the game. Judging from the newspaper quotations given above this player must
have been our gallant captain Cameron. The
account of this game as given in a special to
the Baltimore American seems to be an accurate one. It reads as follows:
`‘South Bethlehem, Pa., May 18.—Lehigh
virtually won the Intercollegiage Championship in Lacrosse by defeating the Johns Hopkins team 5 to 0. The first-half was exciting,
the Johns Hopkins defense showing up particularly fine,especially on the part of Mitchell,

Cone and Dawson. To these men is due the
credit of saving at least seven goals in this
half. The ball during the half was in Hopkins territory at least three-fourth of the time.
The playing of Janney throughout the game
was a feature. The second half opened with
the Lehigh's getting the ball, and after a succession of brilliant passes securing the first
goal, which was thrown by Bartles. The
crowd, which was highly representative of
Lehigh men, went wild and their vigorous
yelling inspired their men with renewed
energy. From the scoring of their first goal
the Lehigh team played with a vim and dash
seldom equalled in the history of the Intercollegiate League.
‘`The second goal was scored notwithstanding the efforts of the Hopkins defense. By
this time the Hopkins men were evidently
fast becoming demoralized and the Lehigh
men scored three remaining goals in quick
succession. Mr. Arnold Reese of Baltimore,
refereed the game. It was he who introduced
lacrosse at Lehigh. His refereeing was firstclass, and was entirely satisfactory to both
teams. Mr. Albert Lefever, Johns Hopkins,
'94, umpired for Johns Hopkins. Mr. Springfield Baldwin, Lehigh, '96, umpired for
Lehigh.'
The make-up of the team for that year was:
J. F. Mitchell, goal; S. M. Cone, point;
P. M. Dawson, cover point; J. B. Crenshaw,
first defense; A. K. Stevens, second defense;
F. A. Lupton, third defense; S. S. Janney,
centre; H. M. Wilson, J. E. Shaw, third
attack; T. F. P. Cameron, second attack; H.
W. Kennard, first attack; M. B. Hill, out
home; G. H. Hodges, in home.
Substitutes—A. C. Bryan; R. E. Belknap;
L. M. Warfield; T. F. Cameron, captain;
J. Hall Pleasants, Jr., manager; Dudley
Williams, assistant manager.
Dudley Williams, Vice-President Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association. M. W. Hill,
Executive Committee of Intercollegiate
Lacrosse Association.
(To he continued).

MAXIMS FOR ATHLETIC SUCCESS.
Michael C. Murphy, trainer of the American Olympic Team, gives the following advice
to athletes:
Find the event for which you are best suited
and stick to it.
Make sure that your diet is simple and eat
slowly.
Do not touch cigarettes or champagne.
Don't expect to be a champion the first
year.
If you are a schoolboy don't train hard before You are eighteen or nineteen years old.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Don't get discouraged and quit because
some other man seems to be making more
progress than you.
Remember that a clean life, a simple diet
and determination will accomplish wonders.

recently been completed by Manager Warren
Stewart, is undoubtedly the best that the
university team has ever had. The schedule
follows:

at Washington (2 Mile Relay entries in main
events). Columbia University Meet, New
York (1 Mile Relay).
February 20th—Federal Gaines, at Washington.
February 22nd—Cross Country Championships, at Washington.
February 27th—Richmond College Meet, at
Richmond.
March 6th—Georgetown Meet, at Washingington.
March 13th—Fifth Regiment Meet, at Baltimore (Relay with Virginia probable),
April 14th—University of Pennsylvania
Relay Carnival.
May 1st—Dual Meet with Navy, at Annapolis.
May 8th—Dual Meet with Virginia, at
Homewood.
May 15th-1)ual Meet with Swarthmore, at
Homewood, pending.
May 22nd—Dual Meet with Columbia, at
Homewood, pending.

THE DANCE.
terram quatiunt ede! The second
of the series of dances given under the auspices of the Cotillion Club was held in McCoy
Hall on February 8th. The hall was beautifully decorated with banners and class flags;
the musicians sat behind a bank of green
palms. But—these are only minor details.
Baltimore has a world-wide reputation for
beautiful girls and any one present at the
dance will certainly vouch for it. Even Dr.
Mustard.
The Dance Committee certainly deserves
great credit for the successful way in which
the dances are carried off. The former ones
were very successful, but this one eclipsed
them all.

THE SENIOR BANQUET.
The senior banquet took place on Friday,
February the 5th, at the New Howard Hotel.
Tradition, we believe, asserts that senior banquets are solemn and dignified affairs. As it
is not polite to contradict tradition, we will
not attempt to draw a vivid picture of 'bread
crumbs bursting in air" and a general atmosphere of good humor, but rather accept the
traditional picture of mournful and silent
young men gathered round a frugal meal.
The occasion was relieved by the presence of
several freshmen, who, however, happened in
intentional& and afforded no amusement from
the point of view of captives. Mr. Guerard,
as toastmaster, was ideal. Several men made
speeches, mostly on traditional topics, such as
``The Class," -The University" and -Athletics." Several other speeches were made,
the titles of which are for certain reasons reserved. During the banquet the awarding of
various honors was made. Among these were:
(1) Most popular man, Mr. Lowndes and Mr.
Baily (tie). (2) The biggest grind, Mr.
Fisher (unanimous). (3) The Candy Kid,
Mr. Onion.
Determination was expressed to support the
University in every possible way after graduation, and it was voted to hold reunions as
frequently as possible. The banquet broke
up somewhat earlier than is usual, perhaps,
for senior banquets, but it was an occasion
that will long be remembered by all those who
were present.

SCIENTIFIC ASSOCIATION.
The Scientific Association met in Hopkins
Hall on Wednesday, February 4th, Professor
Halstead, of the Medical School, was the
first speaker. His paper was on the effects of
excision and transplantation of the parathyroid glands; with a resume of the work
done on this subject at the universities of
Upsala and Vienna and at Johns Hopkins.
Dr. J. A. Anderson, instructor in astronomy,
spoke on the aurora borealis and the recent
theories in regard to the nature of this
phenomenon.

EDITORIAL.
OMETIME ago one of the weekly journals published an article which
urged, in a half-serious way, the appointment of a professor-ofthings-in-general on every college faculty. The writer perceived the
fact (which, indeed, does not need to be pointed out to thoughtful college men) that the enormous broadening of the range of learning at
the present time, and the rage for specialization, are producing onesided men in our universities. Thus even in Johns Hopkins, when
a class reaches its senior year, it is divided up into the biology men,
and the chemists, and the Latinists, and the athletic men, and so on.
In spite of compulsory studies, the degree of A. B. is getting to mean
less and less a 'well-rounded education." For this reason, our writer suggested the creation
of a professor who should make it his duty to stimulate the students to look beyond their
special courses. While, as we all know, the range of tastes and studies is too great for any
one man to be such a professor-of-things-in-general to all the student-body, it is possible that
every student have a private course of his own. The writer finds his course-of-things-ingeneral in a little class, tucked away in the corner, and frequented by but three or four. The
instructor does not consider it necessary to limit himself to the strict letter of his subject, but
often takes the opportunity to digress and discuss art, politics, and the topics of the day.
Of course, not every study permits treatment of this kind. The writer has the good
fortune to be a member of another class, in an entirely different department. Owing to the
nature of the subject, the instructor must occupy himself with a great mass of detail and
minor differences. But he does not stop there. Through the bewildering maze of his
material he presents the great principles of a great science in such a way that his students
take delight in going outside the work of the class to discover and learn for themselves.
Unfortunate the Johns Hopkins man who has not upon his schedule at least one
course-of-things-in-general; and happy he who finds in every study a broadening and stimulating influence.

E have read with interest the first two articles in The Independent regarding American Universities. In these two are treated Harvard
and Yale. If we were choosing our college from the facts thus presented we should choose Yale, notwithstanding the writer of the
series considers Harvard the better.
It seems strange to us that a college man, as Dr. Slosson is,
should not understand what is meant by college democracy. There
VVV;
;V„trigVArsis in the mind of every present-day college man a clearly defined idea
!Or'OV'er
of
college democracy and this idea is the same all over the American
:Of V V
college world. Dr. Slosson merely sees the striving after it, and
imagines that because the strivings take different form that college democracy is different in
each institution.
A college is democratic when each student is first of all, a college man, that is a Hopkins man, etc., second, a fraternity or club man, and last of all an individual with personal
tastes
A class is democratic when its members in an election vote for the men they think best
fitted for the offices, and fraternity brothers do not vote for fraternity brothers, and non-frat.
men for non-frat. men, regardless of their qualifications for the place.
A student is democratic when, for instance, in voting for the captain of an athletic
team he will vote for the man he personally detests, if he thinks he is the best man for the job.
The Yale custom of frowning upon valets and automobiles, is to prevent the University
from being divided up into a rich and poor class.
It is not the use of Greek letters that is primarily objected to at Princeton; it is the
modern Greek-letter fraternity system which, in some cases, breaks the University up into a
number of small cliques, and is thus a foe to college democracy.
In other words college democracy strives to develop first of all a Yale man, a Princeton
man, etc., and incidentally, if desired, a frat. or society man.
It strives to place every student upon an equal footing in college affairs.
It strives to produce college unity.
It differs from college spirit in being internal, whereas college- spirit is external, altho
they are by no means independent.

UST as this issue of the NEWS-LETTER is going to press, the daily
papers make the important announcement that the trustees of the
university have decided to institute an Advisory Council of Alumni.
This council is to advise the trustees in their actions, to hustle for
Homewood, and in general to bridge the gulf between the powers
that be and the student, past and present.
From an undergraduate point of view, the innovation is good
all around. We believe that much of the half-heartedness of the

A body of men who have done so much for science, for letter;, and for the public service, will
surely do much for their alma mater if given half a chance.
Dr. E. F. Slosson, author of the much-discussed articles in The indePendenl, remarks upon
the difference between the alumni of the Western and Eastern universities. In the West they
have been extremely radical, sometimes going to.the Legislature to force the State University
faculties to make innovations; in the East they have been morbidly conservative,in many cases.
We believe that the Johns Hopkins alumni will go neither to one extreme nor to the other,
but will pull together with trustees, faculty, and students for a wisely-planned, steady progress.
Won't we all make a fine team when we get a-going?

THE OPAL RING.
"Yes," said my friend, Jean, the village
priest. "In following my duties as priest of
these pious, but ignorant, people, I have
been called upon to be present at many deathbeds. At almost all of these I have heard the
stories of queer lives. Perhaps the most
startling story I have ever heard, and, at least,
one that will always remain in my mind as
the most awful, was among the first I heard
in this parish and, indeed, it happened at my
second visit to a dying man."
My old friend stopped and seemed to be
lost in a deep reverie. I saw a shudder run
through his body and an indescribable look
came into his face as he thought again of the
scene. Knowing him well, I did not hurry
him, but sal still, smoking an old clay pipe
and drinking ale, until with a sigh the old
priest began his tale.
"To begin with, you must know something
of the old fellow who told me this biography.
He lived in the old house that still stands on
the road leading from the village into the
forest, and allowed no one to come near his
house but his servant, who had been his constant friend and companion for sixty years.
When I undertook this charge I was told to
leave Daniel—this was the only name he had
as far as the villagers were concerned—alone,
and I am ashamed to say that I did as I was
bidden, for he developed a most interesting
character.
"About a year after my arrival, the people
began to notice that the servant had been
neither in the market nor stores for some
time. One old man in the parish became
very curious and, venturing one night to the
house, looked in the only window and saw
the old man Daniel sitting on a low chair beside a rough bed on which his faithful serGreatly
vant lay tossing and groaning.
alarmed he came to me at once and told me
what he had seen. I immediately seized my
medicine case and rushed to the lonely house.
I knocked repeatedly and, as no one opened
the door. I pushed my way into the only
room. There the old man still sat, looking at
his sick servant. I saw at once that he was
dying in a burning fever and I did all I could
to make his last moments comfortable. During
my efforts Daniel sat dazed watching my

efforts in an indifferent manner. When his
servant died he got up, walked around the
room and, running to me, said sharply, "you
have done enough, now go! Come again one
week from tonight!"
"The next Friday night I presented myself
at his door, and he opened it and admitted me
into the bare room. In one corner stood the
rude bed, in another a small, fireless stove, in
another a few clothes hung upon the wall, and
in another, leaning against the wall, stood a
pick and shovel with fresh dirt upon them.
I guessed that he had just buried his old
companion. In the centre of the room stood
an old table, covered with books. On it there
was a bottle of wine, a battered plate filled
with cakes, glasses, and a large red lamp
which cast a glow over everything. There
were two large arm chairs, on either side
of the table, which looked out of keeping
with the other furniture of the room.
"Daniel motioned me into one of these
chairs and there we sat for some time, silently
looking at each other. At last the old man
got up, filled my glass with the rare old wine
and, after pouring out a second glassful, sat
down. So we sat for the remainder of the
evening. While there, my glances took in
all the books on the table and I saw, with a
great shock, that there lay a well worn Bible,
surrounded by every kind of fiction, I was
greatly surprised, for my host was a small
harsh, stern old man with a diabolical look in
his eyes, and I had not expected to find a
Bible in his house. When at last I arose to
go, the old gentleman said in his sharp tone,
'Come again next week,' and let ine out the
door.
"This happened for several weeks, until at
last a kind of friendship sprang up between
us. Then we often sat until the wee small
hours discussing matters pertaining to religion and politics. I soon found out that my
friend knew more than I. Although I often
tried to get him to tell me of his former life,
he would always shut up like a clam when I
mentioned the past, and so I learned to curb
my'curiosity.
"Things went on in this fashion for a year,
until one Friday night, as usual, I walked
down the road toward my friend's house,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

thinking of the old man and wondering what
tale of sorrow he could tell if he would. As
I neared the house, I saw with alarm that
th2re was no light shining fi 0:11.the window.
I knocked, but got no response. When at
last I pushed the door open I heard a low
groan from the bed.
Rushing across I
grasped my friend's hand and felt his rapid
pulse. Instantly I knew that he was dying
from the same fever that had carried off his
old servant a few months before, and that I
could do nothing for him.
He asked for water, and when I gave it
to him drank eagerly, and then said, 'Sit
down, I want to tell you something.' I did
as he asked and then listened, with many
interruptions for water, to a story such as I
have never heard -since.
"'Father, you have been very kind to me,
and beforel die I want to tell this and ask
you to bury me according to the Church.'
"Here the old man stopped and drew a
long breath, and then he continued:
"'There was once a rich man in America
who had an only son. This son was the only
joy the old man had, and in him he centered
his hopes and his highest ambitions. He
gave his boy everything he wanted, and,
after his education was complete, he sent him
abroad for travel and further learning. But
the son was very ungrateful, and, after being
turned out by his father, he went into the
West and lived the rough life of a cowboy.
There he met a young girl to whom he
declared his love. She told him she loved
him, but refused to marry him until he proved
himself a man. Determined to win her, the
young man left the State and his old companions and began a new life. Before going he
went to the girl and gave her a heavy ring,
set with a large opal, and told her he would
come back some day for the ring and herself.
Several years went by, and at last the young
man felt himself the man he should be. As he
walked through the woods to their oldtrysting place, he saw a young couple walking
towards to him with their arms around each
other. As he himself was a lover, he stepped
behind a tree in order to let the pair pass him
undisturbed. As they drew nearer, something
about the girl seemed familiar, and a sudden
fear seized him. When at last they drew

5

near to him, he saw that the girl was his
sweetheart. Without a word he fired two
shots at the pair; the young man fell dead,
and the girl fell mortally wounded. Without
a word the young fellow jumped from behind
the tree, fired another shot into the dead man,
and then turned to the girl. She had fainted,
and he bent over her and kissed her. This
kiss seemed to revive her, for she threw her
arms around his neck and whispered: 'Jack,
I knew you would come back. You see, here
is your ring. Take it. You have killed my
brother. I forgive
"Here the dying man stopped short, and,
after some moments of quiet breathing, passed
away. I sat there for some time lost in
gloomy thought."
Here my friend stopped, and, with a deep
sigh, handed me a simple, heavy gold ring,
set with a large, clear opal.

RECENT LECTURES.
An unusually full and varied course of lectures
has been provided this year by the university.
One or another of the various lecture rooms
has been in use almost every day.
Professor A. V. Williams Jackson, of
Columbia, has been lecturing on "The Religion of Persia:"
Fabian Franklin, Ph.D., formerly professor
of mathematics, is giving a series of ten
lectures upon "The Principles of Political
Economy."
Professor Felix Schelling, of the University
of Pennsylvania, has completed a series upon
"The Elizabethan Drama," given before the
English seminary.
Dr. Stevenson, of Rutgers, is lecturing
upon "The Age of Discovery" before the
historical seminary.
Dr. David M. Robinson, associate professor
of classical archaeology, spoke upon "Stages
in the Life of Ancient Greece" on the evening
of February 5th.
Dr. 0. L. Fassig, of the Maryland State
Weather Bureau, gave a series of lectures on
"Meteorology" before the department of
geology.
The February meeting of the Scientific
Association, and the address of Mr. Ben
Greet, are reported elsewhere in this issue.

THE HISTORY OF LACROSSE AT
JOHNS HOPKINS.
By WILLIAM C. SCHMFOSSER.

1893.

The lacrosse season of 1893 was a success
in two ways: first, from the financial point of
view, and secondly, from that of the caliber
of the team turned out. Six games were
played and Hopkins won four of these and
second place in the Lacrosse League.
The Hullabaloo of 1894 treats the 1893
season as follows: '`In our first game we
extended to our visitors, the College of the
City of New York, a warm reception, for
which Baltimore Lacrosse teams are justly
famous, by defeating them by a score of 9-1.
In the second game we received an unpleasant surprise. Awed by the former renown
of the famous Druids, our team seemed to go
into a state of lethargy from which it did not
emerge until the game had ended. The
defeat on the whole, however, was beneficial,
as it pointed out the weak points, and aroused
in the members of the team the determination
to remedy its defects. After defeating the
Athletic Club of the Schuylkill Navy, the
first championship game of the season was
played with Stevens. It was an extremely interesting and well-played game in which
Hopkins showed themselves the better ill all
round work and won by a score 6-3. Lehigh

was our next opponent. Their team work
was brilliant and showed from the outset that
they were to win. At the end of the firsthalf the score was a tie, but in the secondhalf their magnificent training made itself
felt and we were easily defeated by a score of
6-3."

'`Our team closed its season very pleasantly
by defeating the Athletic Club of Schuylkill
at Philadelphia.The work of the team throughout the season was good and showed a marked
improvement over the work of the previous
year. The training was more vigorously
adhered to and the team work much improved.
Too much stress, however, was placed upon
'body work' which in many instances interfered materially with the proper use of the
stick."
It is interesting to note that already at that
time the coaches had trouble in developing all.
evenly balanced team with reference to body
work" and ''stick work."
A study of the accounts of the games as
given in the newspapers of that day show
that Janney, Roszel, Symington, Straus and
the other attack men carry off most of the
glory. Occasionally we read of the long
throws of T. D. Penniman and a stop by the
goal-keeper, but seldom of the other defense
players; therefore, we hesitate in giving
these men all the credit for the good work;
no doubt every man did his share.
The team was composed of these:
J. B. Crenshaw, goal; T. D. Penniman,

THE NEWS-LETTER.

point; P. M. Dawson, cover point; F. C.
Newton, first defense; W. S. Baer, second
defense; F. K. Cameron, third defense; T. F.
P. Cameron, centre; S. S. Janney, first
attack; B. M. Roszel, second attack; W. S.
Symington, third attack; T. E. Straus, out
home; B. Phinizy, in home.
Substitutes —W. H. Crampton; B. 13. Cone;
T. D. Penniman, captain; C. W. Baldwin,
manager.
Lacrosse Committee—B. M. Roszel, W. S.
Symington, W. S. Baer.
1894.
As to the team of 1894 we get very enthusiastic accounts showing that lacrosse was by
no means at that time on the wane in Baltimore, and in fact the attendance at the several
games played here rather showed a healthy
growing interest on the part of the general
public.
One writer tells us that ``the work of the
Hopkins team during the past season, notwithstanding the fact that it won only the
second place, was most satisfactory. Active
practice began early in the spring, and continued without interruption until the final
championship game. Enough cannot be said
in praise of the conscientious way in which
nearly the entire team entered into training."
After reading this I was surprised to find that
the record of games played that year showed
that as a matter of fact Hopkins had won only
one, beating Lehigh 6 to 4. Stevens, the
Druids and Cornell gloried over '`the Black
and the Blue" with the following scores respectively 7 to 5, 3 to 1, and 6 to 0.
The game with Cornell at Ithaca was quite
an undertaking. In fact it was then the longest trip a Hopkins team of any kind had ever
made, and the writer believes this record still
holds good today. The great obstacle to overcome was the question of financing, as the
Athletic Association did not have much of a
working fund and the guarantees were small.
In addition to the games mentioned above,
the University played two early practice
games: one with the East Branch Y. M. C.
A. and the other with the Catonsville Lacrosse
Club. The former was not much of a game
to test the Hopkins team because some of 'the
Black and the Blue men played on the Y.

7

M. C. A. team. This game will always be
remembered, however, by an amusing incident
which took place. It was in the latter part
of the first-half when after a missed shot at
goal the ball went behind the same. With
true Hopkins spirit, Lupton, who was that day
playing for Y. M. C. A. and Lilly, centre, for
our team, started after the ball. Lilly badly
checked Lupton who to prepare himself for a
good return check, threw off his cap. It is
remarkable to relate, but the cap fell directly
on the ball and neither Lupton nor Lilly
could locate the ball. After some consternation the tricky sphere was located and the
game went on.
In the Catonsville game nothing of peculiar
interest occurred, except that Janney temporarily had his knee sprained. It may be
of interest to posterity to know that this
Janney knee" was a remarkable and valuable asset to any lacrosse team, as it always
managed to get sprained when the Hopkins
players were winded, but could be reduced to
working condition again in a few minutes.
The men who composed our team that year
were:
J. F. Mitchell, goal; T. D. Penniman,
point; P. M. Dawson, cover point; F. K.
Cameron, first defense; J. B. Crenshaw,
second defense; T. E. Straus, third defense;
S. S. Janney, centre; B. M. Roszel, first
attack; T. F. P. Cameron; second attack; W.
S. Symington, third attack; M. Hill, out
home; G. H. Hodges, in home.
Substitutes—A. R. Stevens; B. Bande; T.
E. P. Cameron, captain; J. E. Shaw; A. C.
Bryan; J. Hall Pleasants, Jr., manager.
J. Hall Pleasants, Jr. was Secretary and
Treasurer of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse
Association.
1895.
We who follow the modern lacrosse teams
at Hopkins are rather amused to read how
the Hullabaloo of 1896 gives the boys of that
year a pat on the back for doing such conscientious practice and training.
They
started in about the first of April and continued until after the last game in May. We
also read that the lacrosse men — with few
exceptions went into training on pledges so
that when the championship season came, the
men were in first rate physical condition and

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

this enabled them to make a creditable showing." We can understand that having no
cage at their disposal, it was practically impossible for them to get any practice up to
April first, if the spring of 1895 was a late
one; but why there should be exceptions to
the training list, history does not show.
It was unfortunate that the management
was able to schedule only one practice game,
and that with the Maryland Athletic Club
which was just sallying forth with a lacrosse
team. This game was won by Hopkins
under the leadership of T. F. Cameron by a
score of 10-0.
Our first championship game that year was
with Stevens at Union Park. Among other
things the papers vouch the information that
-the day was a fairly good one for lacrosse,
although there was a sprinkling of rain, and
a little too much wind at times. The attendance was quite good, a large number of Hopkins students with black and blue flags and
banners encouraging their team with college
yells, repeated at every possible opportunity
offered;" that -the visitors excelled in team
work, but the Baltimoreans were stronger
individually;" that .`Janney's superb playing
was the feature;" that ``Captain Cameron's
leg was injured early in the game, and his
usually fine work was thereby much impeded;"
that ``the Hopkins team was greatly strengthened by Mitchell and Sidney Cone, the former
by his splendid work between the goal posts,
saving what looked like many a sure goal;"
that "Cone was everywhere in the Hopkins
defense field, and again and again he returned
the rubber to the Hopkins attack field by his
long throws" and lastly that ''the Stevens
manager will protest the game, claiming that
two of the Johns Hopkins players are not
bona-fide students." No doubt the manager
discovered that he was in error. The game
ended in favor of Hopkins by a score of 6-3.
Next came our fatal trip to South Bethlehem. Several of the men had not recovered
from the Stevens game, and history tells us
that the mainstay of our attack was so seriously hurt that he was using a cane until just
before the game. Judging from the newspaper quotations given above this player must
have been our gallant captain Cameron. The
account of this game as given in a special to
the Baltimore American seems to be an accurate one. It reads as follows:
`‘South Bethlehem, Pa., May 18.—Lehigh
virtually won the Intercollegiage Championship in Lacrosse by defeating the Johns Hopkins team 5 to 0. The first-half was exciting,
the Johns Hopkins defense showing up particularly fine,especially on the part of Mitchell,

Cone and Dawson. To these men is due the
credit of saving at least seven goals in this
half. The ball during the half was in Hopkins territory at least three-fourth of the time.
The playing of Janney throughout the game
was a feature. The second half opened with
the Lehigh's getting the ball, and after a succession of brilliant passes securing the first
goal, which was thrown by Bartles. The
crowd, which was highly representative of
Lehigh men, went wild and their vigorous
yelling inspired their men with renewed
energy. From the scoring of their first goal
the Lehigh team played with a vim and dash
seldom equalled in the history of the Intercollegiate League.
‘`The second goal was scored notwithstanding the efforts of the Hopkins defense. By
this time the Hopkins men were evidently
fast becoming demoralized and the Lehigh
men scored three remaining goals in quick
succession. Mr. Arnold Reese of Baltimore,
refereed the game. It was he who introduced
lacrosse at Lehigh. His refereeing was firstclass, and was entirely satisfactory to both
teams. Mr. Albert Lefever, Johns Hopkins,
'94, umpired for Johns Hopkins. Mr. Springfield Baldwin, Lehigh, '96, umpired for
Lehigh.'
The make-up of the team for that year was:
J. F. Mitchell, goal; S. M. Cone, point;
P. M. Dawson, cover point; J. B. Crenshaw,
first defense; A. K. Stevens, second defense;
F. A. Lupton, third defense; S. S. Janney,
centre; H. M. Wilson, J. E. Shaw, third
attack; T. F. P. Cameron, second attack; H.
W. Kennard, first attack; M. B. Hill, out
home; G. H. Hodges, in home.
Substitutes—A. C. Bryan; R. E. Belknap;
L. M. Warfield; T. F. Cameron, captain;
J. Hall Pleasants, Jr., manager; Dudley
Williams, assistant manager.
Dudley Williams, Vice-President Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association. M. W. Hill,
Executive Committee of Intercollegiate
Lacrosse Association.

MAXIMS FOR ATHLETIC SUCCESS.
Michael C. Murphy, trainer of the American Olympic Team, gives the following advice
to athletes:
Find the event for which you are best suited
and stick to it.
Make sure that your diet is simple and eat
slowly.
Do not touch cigarettes or champagne.
Don't expect to be a champion the first
year.
If you are a schoolboy don't train hard before You are eighteen or nineteen years old.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Don't get discouraged and quit because
some other man seems to be making more
progress than you.
Remember that a clean life, a simple diet
and determination will accomplish wonders.

TRACK SCHEDULE.
The track schedule for 1909, which has
recently been completed by Manager Warren
Stewart, is undoubtedly the best that the
university team has ever had. The schedule
follows:
February 13th—George Washington Meet,
at Washington (2 Mile Relay entries in main
events). Columbia University Meet, New
York (1 Mile Relay).
February 20th—Federal Gaines, at Washington.
February 22nd—Cross Country Championships, at Washington.
February 27th—Richmond College Meet, at
Richmond.
March 6th—Georgetown Meet, at Washingington.
March 13th—Fifth Regiment Meet, at Baltimore (Relay with Virginia probable),
April 14th—University of Pennsylvania
Relay Carnival.
May 1st—Dual Meet with Navy, at Annapolis.
May 8th—Dual Meet with Virginia, at
Homewood.
May 15th-1)ual Meet with Swarthmore, at
Homewood, pending.
May 22nd—Dual Meet with Columbia, at
Homewood, pending.

THE DANCE.
terram quatiunt ede! The second
of the series of dances given under the auspices of the Cotillion Club was held in McCoy
Hall on February 8th. The hall was beautifully decorated with banners and class flags;
the musicians sat behind a bank of green
palms. But—these are only minor details.
Baltimore has a world-wide reputation for
beautiful girls and any one present at the
dance will certainly vouch for it. Even Dr.
Mustard.
The Dance Committee certainly deserves
great credit for the successful way in which
the dances are carried off. The former ones
were very successful, but this one eclipsed
them all.

THE SENIOR BANQUET.
The senior banquet took place on Friday,
February the 5th, at the New Howard Hotel.
Tradition, we believe, asserts that senior banquets are solemn and dignified affairs. As it
is not polite to contradict tradition, we will
not attempt to draw a vivid picture of 'bread
crumbs bursting in air" and a general atmosphere of good humor, but rather accept the
traditional picture of mournful and silent
young men gathered round a frugal meal.
The occasion was relieved by the presence of
several freshmen, who, however, happened in
intentional& and afforded no amusement from
the point of view of captives. Mr. Guerard,
as toastmaster, was ideal. Several men made
speeches, mostly on traditional topics, such as
``The Class," -The University" and -Athletics." Several other speeches were made,
the titles of which are for certain reasons reserved. During the banquet the awarding of
various honors was made. Among these were:
(1) Most popular man, Mr. Lowndes and Mr.
Baily (tie). (2) The biggest grind, Mr.
Fisher (unanimous). (3) The Candy Kid,
Mr. Onion.
Determination was expressed to support the
University in every possible way after graduation, and it was voted to hold reunions as
frequently as possible. The banquet broke
up somewhat earlier than is usual, perhaps,
for senior banquets, but it was an occasion
that will long be remembered by all those who
were present.

ST. JOHN'S FOOTBALL DATES.
The football team of St. John's College,
Annapolis, will play 11 games next fall, according to the schedule that has been arranged
by Manager T. Reed Mudd. The schedule is
now complete with the exception of one date,
November 16, for which negotiations are still
pending.
The prospects for a strong team are considered bright, as only two of the members of
last season's fast eleven will be lost by graduation. The schedule follows:

October 6—Navy, at Naval Academy.

SCIENTIFIC ASSOCIATION.
The Scientific Association met in Hopkins
Hall on Wednesday, February 4th, Professor
Halstead, of the Medical School, was the
first speaker. His paper was on the effects of
excision and transplantation of the parathyroid glands; with a resume of the work
done on this subject at the universities of
Upsala and Vienna and at Johns Hopkins.
Dr. J. A. Anderson, instructor in astronomy,
spoke on the aurora borealis and the recent
theories in regard to the nature of this
phenomenon.
